text:
When Alexander the Great visited Diogenes and asked if he could do anything for him, Diogenes replied, "Yes, stand out of my sunlight."
Diogenes was known to walk around Athens in broad daylight carrying a lit lantern. When asked what he was doing, he replied, "I am just looking for an honest man."
When asked where he came from, he was the first to declare himself a "citizen of the world" (kosmopolitês).
Seeing a child drinking from his hands, Diogenes threw away his cup and said, "A child has beaten me in plainness of living."
Plato defined a human as a "featherless biped." Diogenes plucked a chicken and brought it into Plato's Academy, saying, "Behold! I've brought you a man."
When someone reminded him that the people of Sinope had sentenced him to exile, he replied, "And I sentenced them to stay home."
When asked what was the most beautiful thing in the world, he replied, "Freedom of speech."
Seeing a shower of arrows from a bad archer, he went and sat by the target. When asked why, he said, "To avoid being hit."
When asked why he begged from a statue, he replied, "To get practice in being rejected."
